Ever encountered a time when you have a few working branches which you update daily? Then youâ€™ll know how tiresome it is to checkout to every branch and typing git push <branch name> . If you havenâ€™t encountered this,try doing it once, youâ€™ll know what Iâ€™m sayingğŸ˜ğŸ˜.
We could always automate these stuff just by a few line of shell code.Itâ€™s quite easy you know. Starting by taking the above said situation,youâ€™ve got 5 branches and you want to push to all these 5 branches. Weâ€™ll write a shell script for it.

cd ~/path/to/git/repository/ #Assuming you are anywhere
for i in 'master' 'dev' 'fix1' 'patch1' 'dope-branch-name'
do
	git checkout $i
	git pull origin $i && git push origin $i
done

This 7 line script can help you save some keystrokes.You should save this script with a .sh extension and can be run by typing sh script_filename.sh So now,what does this mean? Itâ€™s the same thing you type in the terminal with a for loop as for extra a â€œdevâ€ touchğŸ˜ğŸ˜.
The looping variable i will loop through the strings weâ€™ve passed through, these will be our branch names and inside the for loop the variable is passed by a $ prefix. Now wherever we use the $ as prefix for the variable name,the script will automatically pass the variableâ€™s value, just like that :snap:âš¡âš¡. Everything that needs to be executed inside the loop should be between the do and done keywords. The loop will go on till the parameters are over.

Now let us make a script which runs a python program,saves its output to another file and commits it and git push it. Here Iâ€™ll be pushing it to a Gist.

But the way he did was using GitHub Actions, and no I didnâ€™t apply for the Beta of GH Actions. So I made a PythonğŸ script to make something like his. You can find it here.

The shell script goes like this,ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡

nvim filename.json

When running this script, youâ€™ll be first prompted to paste the json text you copied from the Wakatime dashboard. You should delete the current contents and paste the new ones and save it.
